body: @cmyyy The aligned version is the one you need, `.png` or `.jpg` does not really matter, we used `img_align_celeba.zip` which contains `.jpg` files and are faster to load!
@knazeri Which GAN_LOSS did you use ?There are nsgan,lsgan and hinge.
@cmyyy We used non-saturating gan loss as explained in the paper.

But you said in the paper,'Spectral normalization was chosen over Wasserstein GAN (WGAN), as we found that WGAN was several times slower in our early tests.'  I'm confused,since you use SN, i thought you also use WGAN loss. 
And have u compare the nsgan loss with hinge loss?Which works better?
Thanks a lot!

@cmyyy Spectral normalization is a form of regularization which was chosen over WGAN-GP or weight clipping in WGAN to enforce a Lipschitz constraint. WGAN requires multiple iterations of training discriminator which makes it slow. Using Spectral Norm with a classic non-saturating gan, gave us better results and it was faster to train.

We didn't perform an ablative study on the loss function, so NSGAN was just some early experiments we did. We'll probably conduct more thorough research on the loss function, and I'm open to suggestions.
@knazeri I found that you use SN in EdgeModel, but in InpaintingModel you do not use it. Can you give some explanation?

@eugenelawrence SN was introduced to enforce Lipschitz continuity in discriminator by normalizing the largest eigenvalue in the weight matrix. Recent research has shown that the generator can also benefit from SN. But in the InpaintingModel we found it to be too restrictive and slowing down the convergence! 
Using SN in the EdgeModel, helped to create a balance between the discriminator and the generdator which I believe is partly because we only use adversarial loss to train the model. For InpaintingModel, there are style, perceptual and reconstruction losses and basically we don't worry too much for the GAN instability. However, all this is merely based on our observation!

@knazeri,but u said 'To evaluate the model, you need to first run the model in test mode against your validation set and save the results on disk.' ,so which set did you use to evaluate actually?And if you use validation set to evaluate,what is the use of test set?

@cmyyy I guess this is bad wording! I used validation and test sets here interchangeably! To answer your question, we used the test set for all reported statistics!
The validation set is used during training by `sampler` to visualize the output and also for hyperparameter tuning when we designed the model.
